questions.text: A 6 year old child presented with recurrent UTI, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given image is a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG), the gold standard for diagnosing vesicoureteric reflux (VUR).
  • It shows retrograde contrast flow from the bladder into the ureters and even up to the renal pelvis, characteristic of VUR.
  • Recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) in children are a common presentation of VUR, due to retrograde urine flow allowing bacterial colonization of the upper urinary tract.

Other Options:

(B) Vesico-Colic Fistula

  • A fistulous connection between the bladder and colon typically presents with fecaluria (feces in urine) and pneumaturia (air in urine), which are not mentioned in this case.
  • Causes include diverticulitis, malignancy, or Crohn's disease, which are unlikely in a 6-year-old child.
  • Imaging: A contrast study would show contrast leaking into the colon, which is not seen here.

Vesicocolic fistula - Dye is going into the colon while micturating.

(C) Urinary Bladder Hernia

  • A herniated bladder (e.g., through the inguinal canal) may cause urinary retention but does not typically present with recurrent UTIs.
  • Imaging: Would show part of the bladder extending beyond the pelvis, which is not seen here.

Urinary bladder hernia - bladder outpouching inside the Inguinal region.

(D) Urinary Bladder Diverticulum

  • Bladder diverticula are outpouchings of the bladder wall.
  • They can cause urinary stasis and infections, but they do not cause retrograde flow into the ureters, as seen in the image.
  • Imaging: Would show contrast-filled sac-like protrusions from the bladder wall, which are absent in this image.

questions.text: A Delayed Intravenous urogram of a patient is shown.what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Congenital obstruction of the ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) is a common anomaly of the urinary tract.

The proposed etiology includes incomplete recanalization of the ureter during early gestation, aberrant vessel causing extrinsic compression, or other bands/kinks causing PUJ constriction.

Dilated renal pelvis and calyces are demonstrated on urography. Delayed radiographs are usually necessary for demonstrating the point of obstruction at UPJ. With longstanding or high-grade obstruction the kidney may become nonfunctional. When there is insufficient contrast excretion or the ureter is not visualized, the diagnosis can be established by antegrade pyelography.

The given image shows hydronephrotic kidney with abrupt transition to ureter. This is suggestive of PUJ obstruction.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 23

questions.text: A 25 year old female with infertility underwent HSG. The image is given below, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Narrow intercornual angle with infertility this is mostly septate uterus. In cases of bicornuate uterus the intercornual angle will be wide. However it is difficult to distinguish both on hsg images. The image below showing bicornuate uterus.

Unicornuate uterus -

Uterine didelphys- here we can see contrast opacification of both the cornua with two vaginal openings.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 297

questions.text: A 30 year old male met with road traffic accident presented to the casualty with inability to pass urine. He has blood at the external urethral meatus. An RGU was performed. What is the most likely site of urethral injury?
questions.solution:
The image showing dye leaking out from membranous part of urethra suggestive of injury at this site.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 211

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presented with acute onset pain in the right limb. An investigation was performed. What is the name of the investigation?
questions.solution:
Doppler ultrasound is a noninvasive test that uses sound waves to check blood flow through your blood vessels. It can be used to examine blood flow in many parts of the body including neck, arms, and legs.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

Triphasic pattern in seen in arterial doppler

Monophonic pattern is seen venous doppler.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2699.

questions.text: Which investigation is being done here?
questions.solution:
A positron emission tomography ( PET) scan is an imaging test that can help reveal the metabolic or biochemical function of the tissues and organs. It uses a radioactive drug called tracer and can often detect the atypical metabolism of the tracer in diseases before it shows up on other imaging tests. PET-CT is a unique combination of crosssectional anatomic information provided by CT and the metabolic information provided by PET which are acquired during a single examination and fused.

The major source of energy in neurons is glucose ,while in PET-CT 18 FDG glucose is used. Therefore we can see increased uptake in the brain.

Cortex of bone is appearing white indicating it is CT.

If bone cortex appears black with increased uptake in the brain then it is suggestive of PET MRI.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology pg 3844

questions.text: A 11 month old child presented with recurrent abdominal pain. On examination a mass can be felt in the lumbar region. A barium enema study was done. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Intussusception occurs when one segment of the bowel is pulled into itself or a neighboring loop of the bowel by peristalsis. The classic triad of intermittent abdominal pain, vomiting, and right upper quadrant mass, plus occult or gross blood on rectal examination. A contrast enema remains the gold standard, demonstrating the intussusception as an occluding mass prolapsing into the lumen, giving the "coiled spring" appearance (barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space).

On usg - Target /Doughnut sign is seen.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • claw sign/pincer clasp/coiled spring appearance is seen on Barium enema.
  • Target /Doughnut sign is seen on usg.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1144

questions.text: A 30 year old patient presented to the causality after a road traffic accident. He has bruises on his chest. His pulse is 120 bpm. BP is 90/60 and RR is 40. a chest Xray was performed and shown below. What is the next most appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Tension pneumothorax, a life-threatening condition that occurs when air enters the pleural space and becomes trapped, causing pressure to build up. This pressure can compress the lung and shift the trachea leading to severe respiratory distress and even death.

X ray findings of Tension pneumothorax:

  • Hyperlucency: The affected side of the chest will appear darker than the other side, indicating increased air density.
  • Mediastinal shift: The mediastinum (the area between the lungs that contains the heart, major blood vessels, and trachea) will be shifted away from the affected side.
  • Rib spreading: The ribs on the affected side may appear more widely spaced.
  • Tracheal deviation: The trachea may be deviated away from the affected side.
  • Absent lung markings: The lung on the affected side may appear collapsed and have no visible lung markings.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema: This is a condition in which air leaks into the tissues under the skin, causing a crackling sensation

Management- placement of wide bore needle followed by chest tube insertion.

Reference: MacDuff A, Arnold A, Harvey JManagement of spontaneous pneumothorax: British Thoracic Society pleural disease guideline 2010 Thorax 2010;65:ii l 8-ii3l.

choices.text: Isolated osteoma of floor of mouth

questions.text: A 45 year old patient complains of recurrent swelling in one side of the neck. She is afraid of eating food as it worsens the swelling. Imaging was performed and shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a radiopaque material in the mandibular region which is suggestive of sialolithasis.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology pg 3771

choices.text: Localized area of dilation highly suggestive of a foreign body./removed with flexible bronchoscopy.
Focal area of decrease air entry confirms the diagnosis
In complete obstruction, ball valve mechanism to such condition
Prefer way of removing is rigid bronchoscopy

questions.text: A 2 year old child presents with a sudden onset of breathing difficulty while playing. CXR shows unilateral lucent hemithorax with normal left lung. Which of the following statement is true in this condition?
questions.solution:
Unilateral hemithorax in a child with sudden breathing difficulty suggests foreign body in lungs.

It is removed by rigid bronchoscope, not partial.

Focal areas of reduced air entry can also occur in collapse; it doesn't confirm the diagnosis.

Ball valve mechanism occurs in partial obstruction not complete.

questions.text: A 35 year old alcoholic male presented with severe abdominal pain, rigidity and vomiting? His vitals are stable. What is the most effective way to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Gas under the diaphragm is a sign of perforation of the viscera. It is an emergency condition and would require patient stabilization with iv fluid and further exploratory laparotomy to find the cause of perforation and seal it.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 2080

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be seen due to rupture of saccular aneurysm in the brain?
questions.solution:
Subarachnoid spaces (SASs) are CSF-filled cavities that lie between the arachnoid and the pia. Hemorrhage into the SAS is known as subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).Sometimes, blood in the SAS is refluxed into the cerebral ventricles, producing secondary intraventricular hemorrhage. The typical location of SAH (basal cisterns and sylvian and inferior interhemispheric fissures). The gross appearance of a SAH is typically characterized by blood-filled basal cisterns. Rupture of an aneurysm typically leads to SAH.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

Mc cause of subarachnoid Hemorrhage is Trauma.

Mc cause of spontaneous subarachnoid Hemorrhage is rupture of berry aneurysm.

IOC for SAH- NCCT.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 Brain edition 2 pg 123

questions.text: A 25 year old patient presented with fever, cough, breathlessness and night sweats. On chest X-Ray, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy was seen. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Sarcoidosis is a chronic, multisystem disease of unknown etiology characterized pathologically by the presence of noncaseating granulomas. Hilar adenopathy is easily recognized on radiographs. Garland triad/1-2-3 sign/ Pawnbrokers sign, is the characteristic nodal involvement at the right paratracheal and bilateral hilar groups which may be identified on radiography.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no pg 2385

questions.text: A 65 year old hypertensive on multidrug treatment with poor compliance presented with sudden onset breathlessness. A chest X-ray is done and shown below. What is most preferred treatment or such case?
questions.solution:
The above image showing batwing wing opacity suggestive of pulmonary edema.Preferred drug in this case will be iv Nitroglycerine and furosemide .

Furosemide is a diuretic which shifts the fluid from pulmonary to systematic circulation.

questions.text: A 60 year old male presented with fever, expectoration and difficulty breathing. HRCT of chest was performed and shown. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Consolidation is characterized by abnormal dense opacification of the lung parenchyma with obscuration of the underlying vessels.

It may be alveolar or interstitial in origin, though most commonly the alveolar air is replaced by fluid, cells, tissue or pus.

On HRCT, consolidation results in an increase in lung opacity with underlying vessels being obscured.

Air bronchogram are usually seen if the bronchi are patent.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2370

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman landed up in AIIMS emergency after a road traffic accident with GCS of 3. She was intubated and sent for NCCT which was found to be normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
DAI is also known as traumatic axonal stretch injury. DAI typically causes much more significant impairment compared with extracerebral hematomas and cortical contusions.

DAI often causes immediate loss of consciousness, which may be transient (in the case of mild TBI) or progress to coma. CT scan in such patients maybe normal.

 As most DAIs are nonhemorrhagic, Tl scans are Often normal, especially in the early stages of TBI. T2WI and FLAIR may show hyperintense foci in the subcortical white matter and corpus callosum. T2* scans are very sensitive to the microbleeds of DAI and typically show multifocal ovoid and linear hypointensities. DWI may show restricted diffusion, particularly within the corpus callosum. Whole-brain tractography(DTI) may be useful in depicting white matter disruption.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 Brain edition 2 pg 45

questions.text: A 70 -year-old male presents with a history of painful limp. There is no history of drug intake or trauma. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given image?
questions.solution:
Left femoral head is showing some amount of sclerosis and erosions.

The earliest manifestation of advanced disease seen on radiographs is the crescent like subchondral fracture which will eventually lead to articular collapse followed by osteoarthritis.

Image showing Crescent sign.

Causes of AVN-Idiopathic

Fracture of neck of femur

Steroid use.

Conditions like sickle cell anemia, Gaucher's disease

In Tb hip - phemister triad is seen which include:

Osteopenia

Erosions

Decreased joint space

Other signs are wandering acetabulum

Mortar and pestle appearance.

Ankylosing spondylitis- occur in young male, sacroiliitis seen

Rheumatoid arthritis- It is an inflammatory condition involving osteopenia.

KEY TAKEAWAY- IOC for ankylosing spondylitis is MRI

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 3053

questions.text: What is the least useful investigation to confirm the diagnosis of the patient with the following condition?
questions.solution:
Achalasia is an uncommon motility disorder of the esophagus characterized by a loss of primary esophageal peristalsis, incomplete relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter in response to deglutition, increased resting LES pressure, and increased intraesophageal pressure. Barium swallow with the patient erect demonstrates a variable degree of dilatation of the esophagus above a beak-like narrowing at the lower esophageal sphincter. The sphincter opens intermittently under the force of the hydrostatic pressure of the barium column above it to allow bolus passage. A gradual, tapered, smooth, conical narrowing of the distal esophageal segment extending for 1-3 cm in length is known as bird's beak appearance and is the hallmark of achalasia.

The given image shows a Bird beak appearance on Barium swallow suggestive of Achalasia cardia.

The gold standard investigation is Manometry

Upper GI Endoscopy looks for any masses and causes for Pseudoachalasia.

24 hr pH monitoring is used in GERD, not Achalasia.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI'S Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2407

questions.text: Following blunt trauma to the chest, the patient presents to the casualty. Out of the following radiographs, in which case, will you do further evaluation before putting a chest tube in the patient
questions.solution:
Fig I shows opacity in the left lower zone which may be due to contusion or pleural effusion and would require further investigation.

Fig 2 shows herniation of abdominal bowel loops into the chest and would require further investigation to rule out diaphragmatic rupture.

Fig 3 shows pneumothorax and collapsed lung and would require ICD tube insertion.

Reference: Thoracic Imaging, Third edition page no. 2134.

choices.text: Cyst content will cause hypersensitivity if leaked
FNAC should be done to confirm diagnosis
Albendazole is to be given before performing nephrectomy
It's caused by a dog tapeworm

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient with pain in the left flank has presented to the OPD. CT scan was done and shown below. Identify the incorrect statement:
questions.solution:
The kidney Shows multiloculated septate lesion suggestive of hydatid cyst; the patient is usually asymptomatic until the cyst has grown large enough to cause pressure symptoms or rupture. Patients may present with flank pain/ mass or dysuria. Imaging findings are dependent on the stage of the hydatid cyst. Hydatid cysts are categorized into three types depending on the stage of the parasite:

  1. Type 1: Unilocular cyst seen in the initial stage.
  2. Type 2: Cyst with multiple daughter cysts seen in the intermediate stage.
  3. Type 3: Calcified cyst suggestive of parasitic death.

Rupture into the collecting system may result in renal colic and excretion of hydatid cysts in the urine.

KEY TAKEAWAY- FNAC should be avoided as it may lead to anaphylactic reaction if fluid comes in contact with normal tissue.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 122
